Title: Why is the graph of a continuous function to a Hausdorff space closed?
Content: Say I have two topological spaces given by $(X,\mathscr{T}_X)$ and $(Y,\mathscr{T}_Y)$ where $Y$ is Hausdorff. In addition say I have a function $f:X\rightarrow Y$, and let it be continuous. I want to show that $Gr(f):=\{(x,f(x))\mid x\in X\}$ is a closed subset of $(X\times Y)$. In answering this question, could you also provide the "chain of thought" that brought you to the solution. I am aware of what the continuity of the function and the fact that $Y$ is Hausdorff provides me in terms of definition. I am however, finding it hard to find a -link- towards answering the question. Thank you all in advance for your help.

Alternatively, maybe I can use the fact that the graph is closed if the product space X×Y has certain properties. Wait, Y being Hausdorff is important here. What does Hausdorff imply? That any two distinct points in Y have disjoint neighborhoods. Also, continuity of f means that the preimage of open sets in Y are open in X.

Let me think about the complement of Gr(f) in X×Y. If I take a point (x,y) not in Gr(f), that means y ≠ f(x). Since Y is Hausdorff, there exist disjoint open neighborhoods around y and f(x). Let's say U around y and V around f(x) such that U ∩ V = ∅. Then, maybe I can construct an open set around (x,y) that doesn't intersect Gr(f). The open set in the product topology would be a product of an open set in X and an open set in Y. Since f is continuous, the preimage of V under f, which is f⁻¹(V), is open in X. So, maybe the open neighborhood around x is f⁻¹(V), and around y is U. Then, the product f⁻¹(V) × U would be an open set in X×Y. If I take any point (x', y') in this product, then f(x') is in V because x' is in f⁻¹(V), and y' is in U. But U and V are disjoint, so y' ≠ f(x'), meaning (x', y') is not in Gr(f). Therefore, this product set is contained in the complement of Gr(f), so the complement is open, hence Gr(f) is closed.

Wait, is that right? Let me check again. If (x,y) is not in Gr(f), then y ≠ f(x). Since Y is Hausdorff, there's U around y and V around f(x) that are disjoint. Any point in this set would have their first component in f⁻¹(V), so f(x') ∈ V, and the second component in U. Since U and V are disjoint, f(x') ≠ y', so (x', y') isn't in Gr(f). The graph Gr(f) is the preimage of Δ under g, right? Because g⁻¹(Δ) would be all (x,y) such that f(x) = y, which is exactly Gr(f). Since g is continuous (because f is continuous and the identity on Y is continuous), and Δ is closed, then Gr(f) = g⁻¹(Δ) is closed in X×Y. That seems like a cleaner argument.
